slides.title: Git vs GitHub
slides.subtitle:
Complete Version Control Mastery
From Zero to Collaboration Pro

box.content: Time machine for your code - Track changes and collaborate safely

list.text: Code History - See who changed what and why
Full Copies - Every user has complete history
No Single Point - No central server failure

note.text: ğŸ¯ Git is distributed - this is its superpower!

box.content: Distributed version control system for tracking code changes

list.text: Open Source - Free to use and modify

note.text: Fun fact: Git means "unpleasant person" in British slang. Linus Torvalds named it after himself!

list.text: Commit - Snapshot of changes at a point in time

box.code:
Working Directory  â†’  Staging Area  â†’  Repository
      (Files)            (Index)          (History)
        â†“                   â†“                 â†“
   Modify files        git add          git commit
   Untracked/          Staged changes   Permanent snapshot
   Modified files

note.text: ğŸ’¡ Think: Working Directory = Draft, Staging = Review, Repository = Published

box.content: Cloud-based hosting platform for Git repositories

note.text: Key insight: Git is the tool, GitHub is the social network for code

list.text: GitHub - Free for public, paid for private

box.content:
Git is like Microsoft Word
GitHub is like Google Docs

box.code:
# Set your identity
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

# Set default branch name
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

# Set default editor
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"

# View your configuration
git config --list

note.text: ğŸ’¡ These settings are stored in ~/.gitconfig (Linux/Mac) or C:\Users\You\.gitconfig (Windows)

box.code:
# Generate SSH key
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"

# Start SSH agent
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

# Add private key to agent
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

# Copy public key to clipboard
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

# Add to GitHub: Settings â†’ SSH and GPG keys

# Initialize new repository
git init

# Clone existing repository
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Clone with SSH
git clone git@github.com:user/repo.git

# Check status
git status

# Add files to staging
git add filename.txt          # Specific file
git add .                     # All files
git add *.js                  # All JS files

# Commit changes
git commit -m "Descriptive message"

# Push to remote
git push origin main

# Pull latest changes
git pull origin main

# View commit history
git log

# Compact log view
git log --oneline

# View changes in files
git diff

# Show staged changes
git diff --staged

# View specific commit
git show commit_hash

.git/
â”œâ”€â”€ HEAD                  # Points to current branch
â”œâ”€â”€ config               # Repository configuration
â”œâ”€â”€ description          # Repository description
â”œâ”€â”€ hooks/               # Scripts for Git events
â”œâ”€â”€ info/                # Global exclude patterns
â”œâ”€â”€ objects/             # All repository content
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ pack/           # Compressed objects
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [hashes]        # File content by SHA-1
â”œâ”€â”€ refs/               # Pointers to commits
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ heads/          # Branch pointers
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ tags/           # Tag pointers
â””â”€â”€ index               # Staging area binary

note.text: âš ï¸ Never manually modify .git folder contents!

box.code:
# List branches
git branch

# Create new branch
git branch feature-branch

# Switch to branch
git checkout feature-branch

# Create and switch (shortcut)
git checkout -b feature-branch

# Delete branch
git branch -d feature-branch

# Force delete (unmerged changes)
git branch -D feature-branch

list.text: Fast-Forward Merge - Linear history, no merge commit
3-Way Merge - Creates merge commit, preserves history

box.code:
# Switch to target branch
git checkout main

# Merge feature branch
git merge feature-branch

# Rebase current branch
git rebase main

# Abort a merge in conflict
git merge --abort

# Abort a rebase
git rebase --abort

# Add remote repository
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

# View remote URLs
git remote -v

# Push to remote
git push -u origin main

# Pull changes
git pull origin main

# Fetch changes (without merging)
git fetch origin

# View remote branches
git branch -r

list.text: Personal Access Token - More secure than passwords

box.code:
# Fork repository (on GitHub UI)
# Click "Fork" button

# Clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/yourname/repo.git

# Add upstream remote
git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/repo.git

# Create feature branch
git checkout -b my-feature

# Make changes and commit
git add .
git commit -m "Add new feature"

# Push to your fork
git push origin my-feature

# Create PR on GitHub UI
# Click "Compare & pull request"

# Fetch upstream changes
git fetch upstream

# Merge into your branch
git checkout main
git merge upstream/main

# Push to your fork
git push origin main

# Or rebase your feature branch
git checkout my-feature
git rebase upstream/main

list.text: Clone - For contributing to your own repos

box.code:
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: CI Pipeline
on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    - name: Setup Node.js
      uses: actions/setup-node@v3
      with:
        node-version: '18'
    - name: Install dependencies
      run: npm install
    - name: Run tests
      run: npm test

note.text: ğŸ’¡ Automate testing, building, and deployment on every code change

box.code:
# Dependency directories
node_modules/
vendor/

# Build outputs
dist/
build/
*.exe

# Environment files
.env
.env.local

# OS files
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db

# IDE files
.vscode/
.idea/
*.swp

# Logs
*.log
logs/

note.text: ğŸ’¡ Create .gitignore before your first commit for best results

box.code:
# Undo unstaged changes
git restore filename.txt

# Unstage file (keep changes)
git restore --staged filename.txt

# Reset to previous commit (soft - keep changes staged)
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# Reset to previous commit (hard - discard changes)
git reset --hard HEAD~1

# Revert a commit (creates new commit)
git revert commit_hash

# Clean untracked files
git clean -fd

# Stash current changes
git stash

# Stash with message
git stash push -m "Work in progress"

# List stashes
git stash list

# Apply latest stash
git stash apply

# Apply specific stash
git stash apply stash@{1}

# Pop stash (apply and remove)
git stash pop

# Clear all stashes
git stash clear

# Create lightweight tag
git tag v1.0.0

# Create annotated tag
git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Release version 1.0.0"

# List tags
git tag

# Push tags to remote
git push origin --tags

# Delete local tag
git tag -d v1.0.0

# Delete remote tag
git push origin --delete v1.0.0

list.text: Feature Branch - Each feature in separate branch
Forking - Each developer has their own fork
Same File - Different changes to same lines
Deleted File - One branch deletes, other modifies

box.code:
# When conflict occurs during merge/pull/rebase
<<<<<<< HEAD
// Your changes
console.log("Hello from main");
=======
// Their changes
console.log("Hello from feature");
>>>>>>> feature-branch

# Choose one option:
# 1. Keep your changes (delete theirs)
# 2. Keep their changes (delete yours)
# 3. Keep both (manual merge)
# 4. Write completely new code

# After editing conflicted files:
git add .
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict"

feat: add new user authentication system
fix: resolve login page crash on mobile
docs: update API documentation
style: format code according to prettier
refactor: simplify user validation logic
test: add unit tests for payment service
chore: update dependencies to latest versions

note.text: ğŸ’¡ Format: type(scope): description - in imperative mood

list.text: Small Commits - One logical change per commit
Descriptive Messages - Explain WHY not just what
Automatic - From docs/ folder or gh-pages branch
Custom Domain - Use your own domain name

box.code:
1. Create feature branch from main
   git checkout -b feature/authentication

2. Develop and commit regularly
   git add .
   git commit -m "feat: add user login"

3. Push to remote
   git push origin feature/authentication

4. Create Pull Request
   # On GitHub: Compare & pull request

5. Code review and discussions
   # Team members review and comment

6. Address review feedback
   git commit -m "fix: address review comments"
   git push

7. Merge after approval
   # Squash and merge or rebase merge

8. Delete feature branch
   git branch -d feature/authentication

1. Fork the repository
   # Click "Fork" on GitHub

2. Clone your fork
   git clone https://github.com/yourname/project.git

3. Add upstream remote
   git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/project.git

4. Create feature branch
   git checkout -b fix-issue-123

5. Make changes and test
   # Write code and tests

6. Commit with descriptive message
   git commit -m "fix: resolve issue with login timeout"

7. Push to your fork
   git push origin fix-issue-123

8. Create Pull Request
   # On your fork: "Compare & pull request"

9. Participate in discussion
   # Respond to review comments

10. Keep PR updated
    git fetch upstream
    git rebase upstream/main

# Basics
git init                    # Initialize repository
git clone <url>            # Clone repository
git status                  # Check status
git add <file>             # Stage files
git commit -m "msg"        # Commit changes
git log                     # View history

# Branching
git branch                  # List branches
git branch <name>          # Create branch
git checkout <branch>      # Switch branch
git merge <branch>         # Merge branch
git branch -d <branch>     # Delete branch

# Remote
git push origin main       # Push to remote
git pull origin main       # Pull from remote
git fetch origin           # Fetch from remote
git remote -v              # View remotes

# Undo
git restore <file>         # Discard changes
git restore --staged <file> # Unstage file
git reset --soft HEAD~1    # Undo commit (keep changes)
git reset --hard HEAD~1    # Undo commit (discard changes)
git revert <commit>        # Create undo commit

list.text: Permission denied - Check SSH keys or use PAT
Merge conflicts - Edit files, then git add
Push rejected - git pull then git push
Create new folder and initialize Git
Make several commits with good messages
Create a feature branch and make changes
Open Pull Request and merge it
What's the difference between git fetch and git pull?
How do you undo the last commit while keeping changes?
When would you use git stash?
What's the difference between fork and clone?
Three areas: Working â†’ Staging â†’ Repository
